text: Hey Sam, hope you had a lovely weekend! :sunglasses:
Your cave project sounds fascinating, I'm intrigued about the biology and science back story - how will you be showing that?

How are you finding Maya? I remember when I first started learning I was completely overwhelmed - I had also come from a purely traditional background of sketching/painting so I remember feeling quite clunky and slow to understand things.

I found that a lot of repetition helped things click into place with me. Just remember that Maya is another tool in your belt for making artwork and realising your vision, the same as a paintbrush/pencil. :+1:

The renders you have sent through are a little too dark on my monitors; it's looking good so far though and you are right that shadows are going to help you set the mood.
I'd also suggest you can use a little artistic license to fake some ambient light in there so the player can navigate the cave, futhermore; you can use form, silhouette and careful lighting of the environment to 'direct' the players where to go.

Here's a post that goes into this in more detail:
<https://www.worldofleveldesign.com/categories/game_environments_design/silhouette-design-game-environments.php>

attachments.title: Silhouette Design Game Environments
attachments.text: How to Create Unique, Appealing and Memorable Environments with Strong Silhouette. Silhouette Design Game Environments

text: Hope this is of some help! Best of luck with the rest of the project! :four_leaf_clover:

I'm currently waiting to find out what my next assigned show is going to be, so I'm having a little bit of downtime at work. We are encouraged to use this time to develop tools that are going to be helpful for the rest of the team or to brush up on our own understanding of the CFX pipeline etc. I'm using this time to do further study of human/animal anatomy, at Framestore we do a lot of work on creatures and making kind of crazy unrealistic designs look and move in a way that's believable and photorealistic.
Before I can start building 3D CFX rigs for the models we are given, I need to understand the differences in how bones/muscle/fat and skin all interact with each other in real life - so that when it comes to simulating that in 3D, I will have a good starting point.

So as a bit of advice/reassurance - if the 3D stuff is feeling a bit too technical, just remember your knowledge/observations of the real world and your creative vision will come to the rescue! :ok_hand:
